summary_points: 1. GE HealthCare Technologies Inc. entered into two new senior unsecured revolving credit facilities totaling $3.5 billion, replacing prior facilities with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. as the administrative agent, with maturity dates of March 26, 2026, and March 27, 2030, respectively.
2. The new credit agreements decreased the total committed amount from $3.5 billion to $3.5 billion.

3. The interest rate on the new credit facilities will be based on either an alternate base rate or an adjusted Term SOFR rate (for U.S. Dollar borrowings), EURIBOR (for Euro borrowings), or a daily simple SONIA rate (for Pound Sterling borrowings), plus an applicable margin determined by the company's credit rating.

1. Freeport-McMoRan Inc.'s first-quarter 2025 copper and gold production met internal expectations, although gold sales were approximately 100,000 ounces below January 2025 guidance due to Indonesian shipment timing.

2. The company's average realized copper price in the first quarter of 2025 was approximately $4.40 per pound, exceeding the London Metal Exchange average quarterly settlement price of $4.24 per pound.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Freeport-McMoRan does not anticipate a material change to its 2025 annual consolidated sales guidance despite lower-than-expected first-quarter gold sales.
1. Anton Levy was appointed to Warner Bros. Discovery's Board of Directors on March 31, 2025, with a total 2025 retainer of $345,000.
2.  Mr. Levy's compensation represents a change from the 2024 compensation program for non-employee directors.
3.  The press release announcing his appointment is not automatically incorporated into future SEC filings.
1. On March 28, 2025, Southwest Airlines appointed J. Ryan Martinez as its principal accounting officer, replacing Tammy Romo, effective April 1, 2025.
2.  No material agreements or compensation were involved in Martinez's appointment.
3. The SEC filing does not contain any information about future impacts or risks associated with this change in personnel.
1. Mohawk Industries appointed David L. Repp as Senior Vice President, Chief Accounting Officer, and Corporate Controller on March 31, 2025, with an annual base salary of $350,000.
2.  James F. Brunk will continue as Chief Financial Officer.
3.  Details regarding Mr. Repp's bonus and equity incentive plan participation remain undisclosed.
1. Labcorp Holdings Inc. will release its first-quarter 2025 financial results before the market opens on April 29, 2025.
2.  The company will host a conference call and webcast to discuss the results on April 29, 2025 at 9 a.m. ET.
3. A replay of the webcast will be available until April 16, 2026.
1. On March 26, 2025, Visa Inc. deposited $375 million into a U.S. litigation escrow account, resulting in decreased conversion rates for its class B-1 and B-2 common stock.
2. This deposit reduced the as-converted class B-1 common stock share count by approximately 21,297 and the as-converted class B-2 common stock share count by approximately 1,060,049.
3. The conversion rate adjustments are equivalent to repurchasing class A common stock, impacting Visa's earnings per share.
1. Keurig Dr Pepper secured a new $4 billion revolving credit agreement on March 31, 2025, replacing a previous agreement.
2. The agreement's interest rate is variable, ranging from SOFR +0.750% to 1.250% or the alternative base rate plus 0% to 0.250%, depending on the company's credit rating.
3.  A $399 million credit facility is included within the $4 billion revolving credit agreement, and the minimum interest coverage ratio of 3.25:1 is subject to adjustment.
1. On March 31, 2025, T. Rowe Price Group, Inc. completed the relocation of its headquarters to 1307 Point Street, Baltimore, MD 21231.
2.  This 8-K filing reports no unusual changes or significant developments in the company's financial performance.
3. The filing does not include any specific future impacts, risks, or regulatory/legal developments.
1. On March 31, 2025, Humana Inc. completed a public offering of an additional $250 million in 5.375% Senior Notes due 2031, increasing the total outstanding principal amount to $1.5 billion.
2.  The net proceeds from this offering, after deducting expenses, are estimated to be approximately $247 million, intended for general corporate purposes, potentially including debt repayment.
3.  Underwriters and their affiliates have provided various services to Humana Inc., including commercial banking and holding existing senior notes, creating potential conflicts of interest.
1. Jeetu Patel, a director since June 2022, will not stand for reelection at Equinix's May 2025 annual meeting due to time constraints from an expanded role at his employer, Cisco.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report filed on March 31, 2025, reporting an event that occurred on March 25, 2025.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned beyond the departure of one director.
1. Aptiv PLC amended and restated its credit agreement on March 31, 2025, increasing its borrowing capacity to $2,000 million.
2.  Affiliates of certain lenders under the amended credit agreement acted as underwriters for Aptiv's offerings and facilitated its share repurchase program.

3. The amended credit agreement contains customary events of default; if one occurs and continues, the outstanding principal, interest, and other amounts owed could become immediately due and payable.

1. On March 26, 2025, Super Micro Computer, Inc. appointed Scott Angel, a former Deloitte partner with extensive technology and semiconductor industry experience, to its Board of Directors, increasing the number of directors to ten.
2.  Scott Angel's annual non-employee director compensation will be $60,000 plus additional retainers for committee service, and an annual equity grant valued at $255,000.

3. The company issued a press release on March 31, 2025, highlighting the appointment of Scott Angel and Yitai Hu as General Counsel, citing these appointments as support for continued growth, but also warning that adverse macroeconomic conditions may harm their business.

1. On March 31, 2025, AMD completed the acquisition of ZT Group Int’l, Inc. for $3.375 billion in cash and 8,335,849 shares of AMD common stock, with potential for additional contingent consideration of up to 740,961 shares and $300 million in cash.

2. AMD provided an unsecured parent guarantee for ZT Group's existing credit agreement with Wells Fargo, which has a limit of $641,666,666.67 and matures on December 31, 2026, but currently has no outstanding borrowings.
3.  AMD anticipates the ZT Group acquisition to be accretive to its non-GAAP earnings by the end of 2025 and is seeking strategic partners to acquire ZT Group's manufacturing business in 2025.

1. On March 28, 2025, Boston Properties Limited Partnership amended and restated its revolving credit agreement, increasing its borrowing capacity to $2.95 billion and extending its maturity date to March 29, 2030.
2.  The company drew the full $700 million of the term loan facility under the amended agreement on March 28, 2025, using the proceeds to repay an existing loan.

3.  The amended credit agreement includes covenants requiring the company to maintain specific financial ratios (e.g., a leverage ratio not exceeding 60%), failure to meet which could lead to acceleration of repayment obligations.
1. As of March 31, 2025, News Corp had repurchased approximately US$654,634,497.74 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On March 28, 2025,  21,380,408 Class A shares and 10,550,726 Class B shares were repurchased, costing US$434,223,761.49 and US$219,820,981.55 respectively.

3. News Corp intends to continue repurchasing its Class A and Class B common stock from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors, as stated in a filing with the Australian Securities Exchange on March 28, 2025.
1.  David Gibbs, Yum! Brands' CEO, announced his intention to retire in the first quarter of 2026.

2.  During Gibbs' tenure as CEO (since January 2020), Yum! Brands' digital sales exceeded $30 billion in 2024, representing over 50% of total sales, and the pace of annual net new unit development tripled, resulting in more than 61,000 restaurant units worldwide.
3. A succession planning committee has been formed to identify Yum! Brands' next CEO.
1. Lynn Elsenhans, a Baker Hughes board member since 2019, will not stand for re-election at the 2025 Annual Meeting; her departure is not due to any disagreement with the company.
2. The Baker Hughes board will expand from ten to eleven members, effective May 1, 2025, with the election of Ilham Kadri.
3. Ilham Kadri's compensation will be consistent with other non-employee directors, as previously disclosed in the company's March 31, 2025 Proxy Statement.
1. Gregory S. Lovins returned as Avery Dennison's Chief Financial Officer on April 1, 2025, after a medical leave of absence, with an approved base salary of $838,500.
2.  Danny G. Allouche ceased serving as Interim Chief Financial Officer on March 31, 2025, but will remain Senior Vice President and Chief Strategy and Corporate Development Officer.

3. Mr. Lovins' previous incentive plan opportunities (75% of base salary for Annual Incentive Plan and 250% of base salary for long-term incentives) remained unchanged following the annual executive compensation review in February 2025.
1. AIG authorized a $7.5 billion common stock repurchase program as of March 31, 2025.
2. AIG projects a 20%+ Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) in operating earnings per share from 2025-2027, driven partly by generative AI.
3.  The SEC filing contains numerous additional graphics, suggesting a substantial amount of supplementary visual data.
1. On March 31, 2025, EQT Corp completed exchange offers and consent solicitations for EQM Midstream Partners, LP notes, resulting in $3,869,493,000 in Existing EQM Notes being validly tendered.
2.  The percentage of outstanding notes tendered varied significantly by series, ranging from 38.1% (5.500% Senior Notes due 2028) to 99.5% (6.375% Senior Notes due 2029).

3. Settlement of the exchange offers and consent solicitations is expected to occur on April 2, 2025, resulting in the elimination of substantially all restrictive covenants from the Existing EQM Indentures, except for the 5.500% Senior Notes due 2028.
